vaccines.name: Inactivated Influenza (IIV)
vaccines.administration: One IIV dose every year in the fall or winter
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction
- Moderate or severe acute illness with or without fever

vaccines.name: Tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis(Td:Tdap)
vaccines.indication: All people who lack written documentation of a primary series consisting of at least 3 doses of tetanus- and diphtheria-toxoid-containing vaccine
vaccines.administration: Substitute 1-time dose of Tdap for Td booster; then boost with Td every 10 yrs
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction
- For Tdap only, history of encephalopathy not attributable to an identifiable cause, within 7d following DTP/DTaP, or Tdap

vaccines.name: Pneumococcal conjugate (PCV13)
vaccines.indication: For all adults with chronic liver diseases if some other risk factor is present: Age ≥65 years, Cerebrospinal fluid leak, Cochlear implant, Functional or anatomic asplenia, hemoglobinopathies, HIV infection, Chronic renal failure  and Nephrotic syndrome, Leukemia, Lymphoma, generalized malignancy, immunosuppression
vaccines.administration:
Schedule for dual vaccination - A single dose of PCV13 followed by a dose of PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later should be given for adults with liver disease who are ≥65 years or have any of the risk factors (mentioned before) and who have not previously received either PCV13 or PPSV23.
For patients who have previously received one or more doses of PPSV23, a single dose of PCV13 should be given ≥1 year after the last PPSV23 dose was received.
Revaccination with single dose of PPSV23 >5 year in immunocompromised and at 65 years old.
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction to this vaccine, including (for PCV13) to any diphtheria toxoid-containing vaccine, or to any of its components
- Moderate or severe acute illness

vaccines.name: Pneumococcal polysaccharide(PPSV23)
vaccines.indication: All chronic liver diseases patients because they have an increased risk of death from pneumococcal bacteremia & pulmonary complications
vaccines.administration:
- 2 doses for adults aged 19 through 64 years, 5yrs apart
For age 65yrs they need a 2nd dose, at least 5 years since previous dose if 1st dose was given prior to age 65
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction to this vaccine, including (for PCV13) to any diphtheria toxoid-containing vaccine, or to any of its components
- Moderate or severe acute illness

vaccines.name: Hepatitis A (HepA) IM
vaccines.indication: Adults who want to be protected from (HAV) infection For chronic liver diseases patients & for persons who receive clotting factor concentrates
vaccines.administration: 2-dose series with a minimum of 6 month interval
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction
- Moderate or severe acute illness

vaccines.name: Hepatitis B (HepB) IM
vaccines.indication: All persons with chronic liver disease including, HCV infection, cirrhosis, fatty liver disease
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction
- Moderate or severe acute illness

vaccines.name: MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella)
vaccines.indication: Individuals at higher risk of either exposure or morbidity e.g., Healthcare personnel, college students, Military personnel, international travelers, Household and close contacts of immunocompromised persons, HIV-infected individuals who do not have current evidence of severe immunosuppression
vaccines.administration:
- Adults with no evidence of immunity should get 1 dose of MMR unless the adult is in a high risk group
- Individuals at high risk should have two doses separated by at least one month or serologic evidence of immunity
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction
- Pregnancy or possibility of pregnancy within 4wks
- Immuno-compromising conditions
- Severe immunodeficiency
- History of thrombocytopenia or thrombocytopenic purpura

vaccines.name: Zoster (Shingles)
vaccines.indication: Recommended for adults aged 60 years or older regardless of whether they report a prior episode of herpes zoster
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction
- Primary cellular or acquired immunodeficiency
- Pregnancy
- Receipt of specific antivirals 24hrs before vaccination (i.e., acyclovir, famciclovir, or valacyclovir) 24hrs before vaccination, if possible; delay resumption of these antiviral drugs for 14d after vaccination
- Moderate or severe acute illness

vaccines.name: Varicella (Chickenpox)
vaccines.indication: All adults without evidence of immunity to varicella<small><sup>*</small></sup>
vaccines.administration:
- 2 doses
- Dose #2 is given 4—8wks after dose #1.
- If dose #2 is delayed, do not repeat dose #1. Just give dose #2.
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction (e.g. anaphylaxis) Pregnancy
- Long-term immunosuppressive therapy or immunocompromised pts
- Receipt of specific antivirals
- Moderate or severe acute illness

vaccines.name: Humanpapilloma virus (HPV)
vaccines.indication:
-For unvaccinated females through age 26yrs: Complete a 3-dose series of HPV2 or HPV4
For unvaccinated males through age 21yrs: Complete a 3-dose series of HPV4
vaccines.administration:
- 3 doses on a 0, 1–2, 6m schedule. Use either HPV2 or HPV4 for women, and only HPV4 for men
- Must be at least 4wks between doses #1 and #2 and at least 12wks between doses #2 and #3
vaccines.contrain:
- Previous severe allergic reaction
- Moderate or severe acute illness
-Pregnancy

name: Chronic Liver Diseases
ref:
*Evidence of immunity to varicella in adults includes any of the following:
- Documentation of 2 doses of varicella vaccine at least 4 weeks apart;
- History of varicella based on diagnosis or verification of varicella disease by a health care provider;
- History of herpes zoster based on diagnosis or verification of herpes zoster disease by a health care provider;
- Laboratory evidence of immunity or laboratory confirmation of disease.
